refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This class provides an API for defining, querying and modifying ring buffer definitions in a variable database. The boot manager uses these definitions to know which ring buffers to create when the system boots. When the system shuts down, these ringbuffers are also destroyed. Note that no attempt is made to destroy proxy rings on systems remote to the ring's host
describes how ring buffers are represented in a variable database.

listitem.para: When constructing a CVardbRingBuffer object you must supply a pDbUri which is a null terminated string that is a URI describing which database will be manipulated and how that database will be accessed.

file: protocol URI's specify direct access to a variable data base file. tcp: protocol URI's specify a server and port or service that through which database operations will be performed. If access is via a database server, clients that have subcribed to the ringbuffer description part of the database will be notified when that section changes.
Returns true if the database the object is connected to has the ring buffer schema. If not returns false. See createSchema below.

Creates the infrastructure into which the ring buffer descriptions will be placed. This method only does anything if haveSchema returns false. It is therefore safe, after creating a CVardbRingBuffer to immediately invokecreateSchema on it.
Creates a new ring buffer definition. The ringbuffer will be named name and be located in host.
If provided maxData overrides the default size of the data section of the ring buffer. If not provided, this defaults to 8Mbytes.
Similarly, if provided, maxConsumers overrides the default maximum of 100 simultaneously connected consumers.

Destroys the existing ring buffer identified by name@host. This destroys all variables associated with the ring buffer by recursively destroying all items in the directory that contains the ring buffer description.
Given an existing ring buffer definition identified by name@host, modifies the data size of the ring. The data size is the number of bytes of data that can be held by the ringbuffer.

Given an existing ringbuffer identified by name@host, sets a new value for the maximum number of simultaneously connected local consumers to newValue. Note that each remote proxy ring uses one consumer slot.
Returns information about the ring identified by name and host. See PUBLIC VARIABLES, TYPES and CONSTANTS below for information about the contents of the CVardbRingBuffer::RingInfo data structure.
Returns a vector with information about all defined ring buffers.

Associate a canvas position, x, y with the ring buffer name@host. This position is normally used by the experiment editor to save a ringbuffer object's position so that when the experiment is re-loaded the layout of the diagram can be reconstructed from the data in the database.
Returns the X coordinate of the last position saved by setEditorPosition for the ringbuffer name@host.
Returns the Y coordinate of the last position saved by setEditorPosition for the ringbuffer name@host.

refsect1.title: PUBLIC VARIABLES, TYPES and CONSTANTS
refsect1.para: The CVardbRingBuffer class has an internally defined data type: CVardbRingBuffer::RingInfo which is used to describe ring buffers. This data type has the following fields:

listitem.para: Contains the name of the ring buffer. This is a name, not a URI.
Contains the host in which the ring buffer will be created. The s_host and s_name fields can be used to construct the ring URI.
Capacity of the ring buffer in bytes.
Maximum number of simultaneously connected consumers.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This package provides an object oriented interface to the API that maintains ring buffer definitions in a variable database. These descriptions are used to create and destroy ring buffers as a data acqusition system starts up and shuts down.

The package consists of a command ensemble that constructs and destroys objects that encapsulate an API connected to a single database via a database URI. The database URI may be either a file: or tcp: protocol URI depending on whether or not direct or server based access is desired. Using server based access allows notification of changes to this part of the database to subscribing programs, while direct access does not.

The ::nscldaq::vardbringbuffer create subcommand accepts an object name and a URI. This is a constructor for a new command ensembled specified by the object name connected to the database described by the URI. ::nscldaq::vardbringbuffer destroy accepts the name of a an object created by ::nscldaq::vardbringbuffer create and destroys that command ensemble.

refsect1.title: API Objects
refsect1.para: This section describes the sub commands recognized by API objects created with ::nscldaq::vardbringbuffer create. In the descriptions below it is understood that each subcommand is preceeded by its object name for example;

informalexample.para: Uses two subcommands of the rings, object; haveSchema and createSchema. In the subcommand descriptions below the rings command is understood and not shown.

listitem.para: Tests to see if the directory tree needed to represent ring buffer descriptions has been made. If so, returns a boolean true value. If not, returns a boolean fals value.

Creates the subdirectory tree needed by the variable database to represent ring buffer descriptions. If the haveSchema would return true when this subcommand is invoked, it does nothing silently. It is therefore safe (though perhaps not efficient) to write scripts assuming that the schema does not exist.

Creates a new ring buffer definition for a ring named name. This ring buffer will be created in host. The optional option-dict is a dict whose key/value pairs can override some of the default values for ring buffer creation.

If the dict is present and has a datasize key, that key's value must be an integer strictly greater than zero and will be the size of the databuffer section of the ring buffer. While a value as small as 1 is strictly legal, that will not work with data as normally formatted in a ring buffer as that size won't accomodate a ring item header. If not overridden, the default value is 8Mbytes (8*1024*1024)

If the dict is present and has a maxconsumers key, that keys' value must be an integer strictly greater than zero and will be the maximum number of consumer programs that can simlutaneously connect. If not provided, this defaults to 100.
Destroys the ring buffer definition identified by name and host.

Changes the data buffer size for a ring buffer definition identified by name and host to datasize. datasize must be an integer number that is srictly greater than zero. In practice it should be something quite a bit larger than this.

Sets the maximum number of consumers for the ring identified by name and host to maxconsumers. Note that maxconsumers must be strictly greater than zero. The overhead of a consumer slot in a ring buffer is really quite small, since it only contains a pid_t identifying the consumer when one is connected and a get offset into the data buffer.

There is, however some overhead associated with making this large in determinining the free space available for a put as that must be computed as the smallest free space available for all connected consumers.
Returns a dict that describes the definition of a ringbuffer identified by name and host. The dict has the following key/value pairs:
The name of the ring buffer. For this case that will be the same as the ring command line parameter.
The host in which the ring buffer is to live. For this case, that will be the same as the host command line parameter.
An integer that is the number of bytes of data the ring buffer will have.
An integer that is the maximum number of simlutaneously connected consumers a ring buffer will have.
Produces a Tcl list that describes all of the ring buffer definitions. Each list element is a dict of the form produced by ringInfo.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Python bindings to CVardbRingBuffer API class.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This module provides a Python binding to the API that uses the variable database to describe ring buffers. The native, C++ API is described in .

The module provides a single type, the VardbRingbuffer.api type, which encapsulates an API instance connected to a database. In addition, errors are signalled by raising VardbRingbuffer.exception objets.

The VardbRingbuffer.api constructor accepts a single parameter, the URI that describes the connection to the database being manipulated. The URi can be either a file: or a tcp: protocol URI. file: URI's directly open a database file while tcp: URIs describe a variable database server through which all actions will proceed.

If a tcp: URI is used to specify the database connection, applications that subscribe to changes in the ring buffer descriptions will receive change notifications. file: URI connections won't signal notifications.

refsect1.title: API METHODS
refsect1.para: This section assumes you have created an API object named api. All methods are shown as methods calld on that object.

listitem.para: Returns True if the directory structure used to manage ring buffer descriptions has already been created in the variable database. If not returns False
Creates the directory structure needed to manage ring buffer descriptions. If the directory structure already exists, this method silently does nothing.
Creates a new ringbuffer definition. The parameters name and host provide the ring bufer name an the host in which it lives. These two parameters are positional and mandatory.
The keyword parameters allow you to override some default parameter values for the ring buffer.
Provides the numer of bytes of buffering the ring buffer provides. If omitted, 8Mbytes of buffering are created (note 8Mbytes = 8*1024*1024).
Provides the maximum number of consumers that can simultaneously receive data from the ring. This defaults to 100
Destroys the ring buffer definition identified by name and host
Sets a new value for the size of the data buffer of the ring definition selected by name and host to value
Sets the maximum number of simultaneous consumers for the ring selecte by name and host to max.
Returns a dict that describes the ring name@host. The dict has the following keys:
Name of the ring.
Host in which the ring is created.
Number fo bytes of ring buffering provided.
Maximum number of simlutaneous consumers.
Returns a tuple whose elements are dicts. These dicts are described above in the discssion of api.ringInfo().

Associates the position x,y with the ring buffer: name@host. This position is normally used by the experiment editor to restore the graphical layout of the experiment when the editor is being restored.
Returns the X coordinate of the position associated with name@host. This is the position last saved with e.g. setEditorPosition.
Returns the Y coordinate of the position associated with name@host. This is the position last saved with e.g. setEditorPosition.
